comments.text:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1.4) Gecko/20061201 Firefox/2.0.0.4 (Ubuntu-feisty) Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1.4) Gecko/20061201 Firefox/2.0.0.4 (Ubuntu-feisty) No warning is issued. The code below worked then ceased to work without warning. When the cursor moves over the DIV.scroller, the opacity must be set back to 1 (fully opaque) and a click on the revealed area should execute the associated function (which move DIV#area aroud). Toggling the switch for Javascript in Preferences did solve twice the problem then it reappeared. Closing Firefox and restarting it does not cure the problem ! I also tried the same code with the Javascript stored in an external file, but again, no difference. I had various add-ons installed (Firebug 1.05, Web Developer 1.1.4 along with EasyGesture and FireColor). To find out why, I completely uninstalled those add-ons without result. Even if it looks stupid to say (every user says so), I didn't change Preferences prior to the problem, I just installed the above add-ons ! The reason I submit here is because the code worked sometimes then abruptly ceased to work. If I dare to guess, I would say either one add-on or Firefox has changed one inner flag which tells Firefox to ignore events and/or Javascript. The CSS in this case is simply used to position the different elements and decorate them. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Load the HTML code given above 2. 3. Actual Results: The page displays correctly (as I want it !) and the three DIV.scroller appear on screen semi-transluscent, with a background image. Expected Results: 1. The opacity of DIV.scroller should revert to 1 on mouse over and to the default value on mouse out. 2. Clicking the top DIV.scroller should trigger a call to the function toTop(). 3. Mouse down on the two other DIV.scroller should trigger a call to the function scrollIt() Test Lay-out (2)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Home

comments.text:
I deeply apologize for the trouble I caused !

This was not a bug in Firefox but one in the submitted code. The DIV#view was misplaced and intercepted all mouse events that I wanted to use, preventing the expected behaviour from occuring.
